Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Modeling an Environmentally Friendly Catalytic Mechanism to Convert Wax-Covered Poultry Waste into Digestible Protein Meal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural waxes in animals provide their hosts with a form of energy storage or waterproof protection from elements. Waxy lipids present on the surface of chicken feathers, a large waste product from the poultry industry, is thought to hinder biological rendering of the feathers into digestible protein meal for use in animal agriculture. Wax ester hydrolases are a potential catalyst to assist in breaking down the waxes in an environmentally sound way. A biocatalyst with demonstrated ability to hydrolyze wax esters has been sourced from a feather-degrading microorganism found in soil. In collaboration with Dr. Shinya Fushinobu, an expert protein crystallographer at the University of Tokyo in Japan, the project will determine the three-dimensional structure of the biocatalyst as a means to understand its molecular mechanism. This information will advance understanding of biocatalyst function, which can then be used to design a biocatalyst with improved properties to better aid in feather rendering and adaptations for use in other industries such as health care, cosmetics, nutrition, and energy.

A wax-ester hydrolase gene was cloned from a gram-positive Streptomycete isolated from the soil and capable of hydrolyzing chicken feathers. The gene will be heterologously expressed in E. coli, then purified and concentrated for the structure research in the lab of Dr. Fushinobu. Favorable parameters to grow crystals of the enzyme will be determined and optimized using a hanging drop crystallization test. Crystals will then be cryoprotected and used to collect diffraction data using beamlines with a charged couple device camera at the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) in Tsukuba, Japan. After processing the data using the HKL2000 software package, a combination of computational tools will be used to refine and analyze the structural models of the biocatalyst. Based on the determined structure of the wax-ester hydrolase, the enzyme will be rationally designed for improving its stability and catalytic efficiency.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chicken feathers are a major co-product from the poultry industry. Since the feathers are approximately 90% protein they have tremendous potential as a protein source in agriculture. However, the stable nature of the feather protein prevents them from being effectively digested by animals. Through the use of biocatalysts, it may be possible to more effectively utilize the nutrients from feathers for use as a high value protein source and other applications.

Chickens excrete waxy lipids onto their feathers as a form of protection from the elements. By first removing the lipid barrier, subsequent steps breaking down the feather protein may be improved.  A biocatalyst capable of hydrolyzing waxes was identified from a feather-degrading microbe. The purpose of the project was to determine structural characteristics of the biocatalyst to learn how it is able to interact with waxy lipids and provide insight on how to improve the biocatalyst for use in applied settings.   

The project supported early efforts to solving the structure of the wax degrading biocatalyst, which would be valuable information to understanding it’s molecular mechanism. The first step to solving the structure of a biocatalyst is to grow crystals using a highly purified and concentrated sample of the biocatalyst. After screening nearly 400 conditions, two conditions yielded crystals. Efforts were made to reproduce and improve the conditions to grow quality crystals capable of collecting diffraction data from an x-ray source in order to solve the structure. However, the crystals produced from the study were unable to diffract well and new conditions will need to be identified.

While attempts at growing crystals were being made, a homology model of the biocatalyst was constructed. The model was built using the solved structure of a similar biocatalyst as a template. Yet, the similarity between the template and biocatalyst of interest was not high enough to gather any meaningful information from the model.

Activity analyses of the biocatalyst were also supported by the project. Through use of thin layer chromatography experiments, the ability of the biocatalyst to break down waxy substrates was further supported. Other activity tests were also performed to evaluate the biocatalyst’s preferred substrate type. The biocatalyst displayed a broad specificity towards lipid substrates with a preference towards substrates that were more water soluble. 

The training in structural enzymology provided by the project has allowed for the continued study of the wax-degrading biocatalyst. Further efforts are being made to identify new crystallization conditions of the biocatalyst. Also, techniques to build homology models have been applied to a similar biocatalyst in the attempt to improve its specificity towards wax substrates. The further study on wax-degrading biocatalysts will lead to understanding their molecular mechanism at breaking down waxy substrates and has potential for use in applied settings such as the rendering of chicken feathers.


Last Modified: 03/15/2017
Modified by: Matthew Barcus
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Chicken feathers are a major co-product from the poultry industry. Since the feathers are approximately 90% protein they have tremendous potential as a protein source in agriculture. However, the stable nature of the feather protein prevents them from being effectively digested by animals. Through the use of biocatalysts, it may be possible to more effectively utilize the nutrients from feathers for use as a high value protein source and other applications. Chickens excrete waxy lipids onto their feathers as a form of protection from the elements. By first removing the lipid barrier, subsequent steps breaking down the feather protein may be improved. A biocatalyst capable of hydrolyzing waxes was identified from a feather-degrading microbe. The purpose of the project was to determine structural characteristics of the biocatalyst to learn how it is able to interact with waxy lipids and provide insight on how to improve the biocatalyst for use in applied settings. The project supported early efforts to solving the structure of the wax degrading biocatalyst, which would be valuable information to understanding it?s molecular mechanism. The first step to solving the structure of a biocatalyst is to grow crystals using a highly purified and concentrated sample of the biocatalyst. After screening nearly 400 conditions, two conditions yielded crystals. Efforts were made to reproduce and improve the conditions to grow quality crystals capable of collecting diffraction data from an x-ray source in order to solve the structure. Activity analyses of the biocatalyst were also supported by the project. Through use of thin layer chromatography experiments, the ability of the biocatalyst to break down waxy substrates was further supported. Other activity tests were also performed to evaluate the biocatalyst?s preferred substrate type. The biocatalyst displayed a broad specificity towards lipid substrates with a preference towards substrates that were more water soluble. The training in structural enzymology provided by the project has allowed for the continued study of the wax-degrading biocatalyst. Further efforts are being made to identify new crystallization conditions of the biocatalyst. Also, techniques to build homology models have been applied to a similar biocatalyst in the attempt to improve its specificity towards wax substrates. The further study on wax-degrading biocatalysts will lead to understanding their molecular mechanism at breaking down waxy substrates and has potential for use in applied settings such as the rendering of chicken feathers.
